Author: phm87#7395
Content: @blackjok3r  about opensource hardware, I heard about IBM POWER and discussed it with a friend. I will ask him a link but he told me that it is not cheap (3.5k for a small dev station) and specs are limited (but it may be enough for some AC). Opensource hardware is an interesting subject. Whatever I also like AMD, their chips are not opensource

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Yeah I have looked into that also, looks promising but cost is ridiculous at this time.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: For notary node, I just went with the largest server I could get my hands on that dont have any "management engine" things ... Athlon64s dont include any hardware back door that I know of.. BUt they also lack modern instuctions so are extremly slow at some tasks... Hoever 4x12 cores, is still decent, even if power sots a bit mroe hardware cost upfront offset this for a few years at least.

Author: phm87#7395
Content: I heard about some ARM chips that are opensource but I don't think that a coin/AC can run on one of these. I have the same idea about AMD (no known backdoor included) but as AMD chips are closed source and as backdoors are not known before being revealed, I cannot thrust AMD at 100%

Author: Mark81#4505
Content: What is realistic maximum amount of blockchains that one notarynode can handle and run?

Author: Mark81#4505
Content: I believe that running multiple blockhains in parallel is quite resource intensive.

Author: ComputerGenie üë¥üèºüì¢#7004
Content: it currently takes ~28GB of RAM to run the list of assetchains

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: with the latest improvements, the limit is simply how many fit on a single node. so the question becomes what is that number (about 100?) and how many systems can a single operator handle

Author: Mark81#4505
Content: Btc is biggest by blockchain size if ethereum is not counted (who nuthead is even downloading full?). How much blockcain size affects to resources or does it these days?

Author: CHMEX#0686
Content: ripple ( if that counts as a blockchain) is like 50 times of BTC

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there is no genesis block to early blocks for XRP

Author: Mark81#4505
Content: It crossed to my mind too but its ripple üòÇ

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: by definition not a blockchain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: I think RAM usage will be the bottleneck

Author: Mark81#4505
Content: What part clients keep in memory from blochains? Full blockchain or part of it?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: only part, but usually 500MB to 1GB

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so it adds up with 100 chains

Author: Mark81#4505
Content: Hmmm... What if there would be tier1 and tier2 level notarizations? Current notarynode network would hold tier 1 level. Tier2 level would be free for public and would have its own chain for notarizations. And it is of course notarized by tier 1. This way market and coin communities would have chance to choose between both options. Run their own notary service or outsource this to tier 1. I dont know if this makes any sense or not.

Author: Shinzo Abe#9369
Content: @jl777c when creating a decentralized exchange would you do order book based trades where miners can front run the orders that are streamed on the order book..or do you fundamnetally like p2p swaps without an order book like say air swap is doing?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i did minerless orderbooks 4 years ago and that is the same basic design mm2 has

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if there are no miners mining the bid/asks they cant front run

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: also it wont cost a txfee for every change in bid or ask or cancel that you do. that alone almost makes mined onchain orderbooks DOA

Author: Mark81#4505
Content: What is komodo on-demand-block assetchain blocktimes?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: is this a trick question?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you just asked how much time between tx in the mempool

Author: Mark81#4505
Content: No. I am just wondering what is minimum time between blocks.

Author: Mark81#4505
Content: Does assetchains wait before posting new block if last one was second ago.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it uses the diff adjustment and for a chain that is long dormant it would have faster blocks at first, but if there is a period of regular blocks, the diff will slow things down

Author: Mark81#4505
Content: So there is way to set maxinum period for blocktimes?

Author: CHMEX#0686
Content: an example is KOIN koin.explorer.dexstats.info  no block for about 3130 minutes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the max is very hard to set as if there is a lot of hashrate and it disappears, then what is the biggest differnce in hashrate before and after

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: ok, so if 100% of all equihash miners are on a chain and then disappear and then we end up with just a single z9 mini...

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that seems a pretty extreme case, but it goes from 3000 Msols to 0.01 Msols or 300000x normal so it seems worst case is about 300000 minutes between blocks

Author: Mark81#4505
Content: I understand on demand feature but where i am getting is that period where transactions are constantly flowing in --> time then between blocks.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it will end up at one minute blocks

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: assuming constant hashrate

Author: Mark81#4505
Content: How hard would it be create variable blocktime for case when blockchain is needed ie. for games doing their things what ever it mught be?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is not easy to just set a blocktime, but it could be approximated

Author: Mark81#4505
Content: In this case it would make blockchain more useful since transactions would propagate more faster when needed.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: maybe an on demand chain with a faster blocktime

Author: Mark81#4505
Content: It could based into transaction amounts for certain period with blocktimes.

Author: Mark81#4505
Content: Faster blocktime would help.

Author: Mark81#4505
Content: Since it won't be problem with on demand blocks.

Author: Shinzo Abe#9369
Content: @jl777c are minerless orderbooks less secure cause of the lack of mining incentive ?

Author: Shinzo Abe#9369
Content: which AWS skills do you think are going to be the most 'on demand" in the financial/blockchain space?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: well the mining incentive doesnt make them secure, the opposite, it allows frontrunning, etc.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so not sure the question makes sense without more specific details

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the prices are broadcast via multiple relay nodes to all the nodes in the network

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: each node verifies all price quotes via the signature and utxo

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is not as if a node can be confused into swapping at a bad price

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: like any network, a ddos attack would flood the network, but that is an annoyance/disruption, not a direct loss of funds

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: also the relay nodes would be run by holders of the DEX coin, which incentivizes them to make sure the orders are relayed

Author: allbits#5898
Content: Does the CRYPTO asset also benefit (in KMD) from chains that notarize to KMD?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, but the economic value us much smaller than the BTC value, ie 50 BTC vs 50 KMD

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i guess it is 50 KMD * number of chains though...

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: ok, so it might add up

Author: allbits#5898
Content: It might ;)

Author: costa2439#3771
Content:
"also the relay nodes would be run by holders of the DEX coin, which incentivizes them to make sure the orders are relayed"

can you detail this, the asset dex holders? or the exchange currencies?

Thanks

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: DEX

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: https://dex.explorer.dexstats.info/

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: the more successful trades  there are, the greater revs the DEX holders get. so they are  motivated to run the relay nodes, so that orders propagate throughout the network

Author: costa2439#3771
Content: Oh! I understand, Thanks to both of you!
